presentation.title: Surface water supply, mean annual precipitation
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from water regulation and supply by ecosystems under mean annual precipitation levels
presentation.description: Values resulting from the provision of surface and groundwater water supply by ecosystems, including precipitation, groundwater recharge, or delivery of surface water through streams, lakes, or reservoirs.

page.name: Surface water supply assessment at mean annual precipitation levels
page.title: Introduction
page.runninghead: Surface water supply at mean annual precipitation levels
page.description: This model considers surface water supply for various human beneficiary groups, including agriculture, industry, domestic use, and in-stream flow to support hydroelectric power generation, navigation, or recreation. The model uses mean annual precipitation as the primary source of surface water. These models collectively map sources of surface water (precipitation, snowmelt, springs, baseflow to rivers, incoming water transfers), their sinks (areas of groundwater infiltration or evapotranspiration), and user groups and link these via a flow model accounting for downstream water movement.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual precipitation
page.title: Annual precipitation
page.description:
Annual precipitation.

Role in models

Precipitation is the ultimate "source" of surface and groundwater. Precipitation runs off into water bodies where can be used, or recharges groundwater through percolation to aquifers. Data are currently at an annual time scale; finer temporal resolution could be added in the future to better account for wet and dry season water supply dynamics. These data are passed to the flow model to estimate actual water supply used given the locations of beneficiaries, their demand, and infiltration and evapotranspiration that occur as water flows across the landscape.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of precipitation per year.

Source

PRISM Climate Group, Oregon State University (U.S.); WorldClim (global).
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: WorldClim, PRISM
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Incoming water transfer
page.title: Incoming water transfer
page.description:
Incoming water transfer.

Role in models

In cases where water is transferred into a different watershed via tunnels or aqueducts, the incoming diversion is included as a source of surface water for that watershed.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of precipitation per year.

Source

Digitized from relevant regional water management authority data.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Summed surface water sources
page.title: Summed surface water sources
page.description:
Summed surface water sources.

Role in models

This is the summed value of all relevant surface water sources in a given model, which could include precipitation, incoming water transfers, springs, snowmelt, and baseflow.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of precipitation per year.

Source

Deterministically calculated as sum of all surface water sources.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual groundwater recharge
page.title: Annual groundwater recharge
page.description:
Annual groundwater recharge, wet year.

Role in models

Groundwater recharge data are the "source" of groundwater. Groundwater then moves through aquifers based on various geologic factors, or is extracted by wells for human use. These data are passed to the flow model to estimate actual groundwater used given the locations of beneficiaries and their demand, along with any springs or baseflow to rivers that naturally returns groundwater back to surface water.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of groundwater recharge per year.

Source

U.S. Geological Survey.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: U.S. Geological Survey.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Slope
page.title: Slope
page.description:
Slope affects runoff by influencing potential infiltration.

Role in models

Since hydrologic soils group classifications do not account for slope, slope data along with HSG and impervious surface data are used to estimate the soil infiltration component in the surface water sink models. Greater infiltration is expected on level slopes than on steep slopes where runoff occurs quickly.

Representation

Data are in physical units of degrees slope.

Source

Derived from a global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Derived from Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Hydrologic soils group
page.title: Hydrologic soils group
page.description:
Different soil types have different infiltration capacities. See Computing composite CN and runoff coefficients.

Role in models

Soils are classified from group A (highest infiltraiton capacity) to D (lowest infiltration capacity); group accounts for maximum yearly wetness, degree of soil freezing, bare soil surface, and swelling of clays, but does not account for slope. HSG is used along with slope and impervious surface data to estimate the soil infiltration component of surface water sink models.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

University of Vermont Spatial Analysis Lab, derived from FAO soils data.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Percent impervious cover
page.title: Percent impervious cover
page.description:
The amount of impervious surface (e.g., buildings, pavement) on the landscape.

Role in models

Impervious surface data are used along with slope and hydrologic soils group to estimate the soil infiltration component of the surface water sink models. Zero infiltration is expected on impervious surfaces.

Representation

Data show the percentage of the land surface with impervious cover.

Source

NOAA-NGDC global impervious surface data.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Data source: Data source: NOAA-NGDC global impervious surface data/br> Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Mountain front recharge zones
page.title: Mountain front recharge zones
page.description:
The intersection of valley fill alluvium and mountain fronts.

Role in models

In the basin and range geologic formations like in the southwestern United States, mountain fronts are a key location for groundwater recharge. These data are thus used as an input to a probabilistic model of infiltration.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of potential mountainfront recharge zones, represented as a 1,600-meter wide band around the base of mountainfronts where subsurface geology shifts to valley fill alluvium. Areas of limestone bedrock, which promote high levels of infiltration, are also included in this layer.

Source

Derived from Arizona Geographic Information Council geology data.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Geographic Information Council.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Stream channels
page.title: Stream channels
page.description:
Perennial, intermittent, and ephemeral stream channels.

Role in models

Along with mountain fronts, stream channels are another important recharge zone in the southwestern United States. These data are thus used as an input to a probabilistic model of infiltration.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of perennial, intermittent, or ephemeral stream channels.

Source

Arizona Geographic Information Council.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Geographic Information Council.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil infiltration
page.title: Soil infiltration
page.description:
Surface water absorbed by the soil, potentially becoming available as groundwater.

Role in models

This is the output of a probabilistic model accounting for the influence of soil and geologic characteristics on infiltration. Results are summed with evapotranspiration to give total surface water sink values, and then passed to the flow model to estimate actual surface water availability given the location of sources of surface water and users of water. In the absence of direct data on infiltration, the results of this model can also be used as source data for groundwater flow models.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water infiltrated per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of water infiltrated. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area. USGS WRD NDSI groundwater recharge data were used for Bayesian network training.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: USGS groundwater recharge data.
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual maximum temperature
page.title: Annual maximum temperature
page.description:
Annual maximum temperature influences water demand by plants and potential levels of evaporation.

Role in models

Particularly in water limited environments, annual maximum temperature is used as an influence on evapotranspiration, with greater evapotranspiration under higher temperatures.

Representation

Data are in physical units of degrees Celsius.

Source

PRISM Climate Group, Oregon State University (U.S.); WorldClim (global).
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: WorldClim, PRISM
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different vegetation types will promote or reduce infiltration and evapotranspiration.

Role in models

Vegetation type is used as an input to a probabilistic model for evapotranspiration, which is part of the sink model for surface water.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from land cover classes.

Source

Southwest Regional GAP Analysis (SWReGAP) land cover data.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Southwest Regional GAP Analayis land cover data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different vegetation types will promote or reduce infiltration and evapotranspiration.

Role in models

Vegetation type is used as an input to a probabilistic model for evapotranspiration, which is part of the sink model for surface water.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from land cover classes.

Source

Southwest Regional GAP Analysis (SWReGAP) land cover data.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Southwest Regional GAP Analayis land cover data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different vegetation types will promote or reduce infiltration and evapotranspiration.

Role in models

Vegetation type is used as an input to a probabilistic model for evapotranspiration, which is part of the sink model for surface water.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from land cover classes.

Source

Veracruz land cover data.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different vegetation types will promote or reduce infiltration and evapotranspiration.

Role in models

Vegetation type is used as an input to a probabilistic model for evapotranspiration, which is part of the sink model for surface water.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from land cover classes.

Source

AFRICOVER land cover data.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: FAO Africover land cover data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Percent tree canopy cover
page.title: Percent tree canopy cover
page.description:
Percent tree canopy cover. Tree canopy cover influences root and canopy characteristics that affect transpiration rates.

Role in models

Tree canopy cover is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation toward evapotranpiration. All else being equal, expect greater evapotranspiration is assumed under higher tree canopy cover.

Representation

Data show the percentage of the land surface under tree canopy cover.

Source

)NLCD 2001 data (U.S.); GLCF (University of Maryland, global).
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data sources: National Land Cover Dataset, University of Maryland Global Land Cover Facility.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Evapotranspiration
page.title: Evapotranspiration
page.description:
Total surface water evaporated or taken up by vegetation and transpired, becoming no longer available as surface or groundwater.

Role in models

This is the output of a probabilistic model accounting for the influence of vegetation and climatic characteristics on evapotranspiration. Results are summed with infiltration to give total surface water sink values, and then passed to the flow model to estimate actual surface water availability given the location of sources of surface water and users of water.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water evaporated or transpired per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of water infiltrated. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area. University of Delaware Global Water Balance data were used for Bayesian network training.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: University of Delaware Global Water Balance data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Surface water sink
page.title: Surface water sink
page.description:
The sum of infiltration and evapotranspiration, e.g., all surface water that returns to the atmosphere or infiltrates to groundwater, becoming unavailable as downstream surface water.

Role in models

The surface water sink is the total water that was once surface water but is no longer available as surface water. These data are passed to the surface water flow model, which calculates actual surface water availability for beneficiaries, given precipitation levels, the activity of sinks, and use of and demand for water.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water infiltrated, evaporated, or transpired per year.

Source

Calculated as the sum of outputs from a probabilistic models for infiltration and evapotranspiration.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Industrial surface water use
page.title: Industrial surface water use
page.description:
Water use by industrial water users.

Role in models

Results are summed with other types of water users to give total water demand. Total demand is passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water used per year.

Source

Instituto de Ecologia, INECOL.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Agricultural surface water use
page.title: Agricultural surface water use
page.description:
Water use by agricultural water users.

Role in models

Results are summed with other types of water users to give total water demand. Total demand is passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water used per year.

Source

Instituto de Ecologia, INECOL (Mexico); Colorado Division of Water Resources (Colorado).
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Colorado Division of Water Resources.
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.name: Residential surface water use
page.title: Residential surface water use
page.description:
Water use by residential water users.

Role in models

Results are summed with other types of water users to give total water demand. Total demand is passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water used per year.

Source

Instituto de Ecologia, INECOL (Mexico); U.S. Census data on households and EPA data on per household water consumption (Colorado).
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Aquacultural surface water use
page.title: Aquacultural surface water use
page.description:
Water use by aquacultural water users.

Role in models

Results are summed with other types of water users to give total water demand. Total demand is passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water used per year.

Source

Instituto de Ecologia, INECOL.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Hydraulic fracturing surface water use
page.title: Hydraulic fracturing surface water use
page.description:
Water use by hydraulic fracturing water users for natural gas extraction.

Role in models

Results are summed with other types of water users to give total water demand. Total demand is passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water used per year.

Source

Colorado Oil and Gas Conservation Commission (Colorado).
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Colorado Oil and Gas Conservation Commission.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Total surface water use
page.title: Total surface water use
page.description:
The sum of water use by residential, industrial, agricultural, and aquacultural water users.

Role in models

Results are the final water use values. These are passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water used per year.

Source

Calculated deterministically as the sum of residential, industrial, agricultural, and aquacultural water use.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Surface diversion capacity
page.title: Surface diversion capacity
page.description:
Surface diversions, primarily for agriculture, are an important surface water user, and are the only surface water user for our San Pedro case study.

Role in models

Results are the final surface water use values for the San Pedro. These are passed to the flow model to estimate actual water availability given the location of sources of fresh water, evapotranspiration and infiltration, and demand for water.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water diversion capacity per year.

Source

Digitized locations and diversion capacity for surface diversions in the San Pedro watershed.
page.see-also:
Lacher, L.J. 1994. Hydrologic and legal issues of the Upper San Pedro River Basin, Arizona. Semi-Arid Land-Surface Atmosphere Program (SALSA) Online Publication.
Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Lacher, L.J. (1994)
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Well pumping capacity
page.title: Well pumping capacity
page.description:
Groundwater well locations and use data, where available, are the source of use data for groundwater flow models.

Role in models

Results are the final groundwater use values for the San Pedro. These could be passed to a groundwater flow model to estimate actual groundwater availability given the location of infiltration zone locations and groundwater recharge quantities and demand for water.

Representation

Data are in physical units of millimeters of water pumping capacity per year.

Source

Arizona Department of Water Resources (U.S.); INECOL (Mexico).
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Department of Water Resources Wells-55 Database.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Elevation
page.title: Elevation
page.description:
Elevation above sea level.

Role in models

A digital elevation model is used along with hydrography data to route water across the land surface. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which water then follows through the stream network.

Representation

Data are in physical units of meters above sea level.

Source

Global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Rivers
page.title: Rivers
page.description:
River and stream locations.

Role in models

Hydrography data are used to route surface water. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which water then follows through the stream network.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of rivers and streams.

Sources

Arizona Geographic Information Council; Colorado Department of Transportation; Veracruz hydrgraphy data.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Geographic Information Council, Colorado DOT.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Possible surface water flow
page.title: Possible surface water flow
page.description:
*Possible flow maps* show the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows the movement of surface water via topography and stream networks, when not accounting for sinks (infiltration or evapotranspirative losses of surface water).
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Possible surface water supply
page.title: Possible surface water supply
page.description:
*Possible source maps*, generated through flow analysis, show which specific sources actually generate carriers that reach users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account use values and the carrier flow paths. Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity can actually reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the sources that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This map shows the initial location of surface water that is capable of providing water to human beneficiaries when accounting for flow paths but not accounting for sinks (i.e., potentially can provide water to human beneficiaries).
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Possible surface water use
page.title: Possible surface water use
page.description:
*Possible use maps* show the locations of users that can receive a benefit due to flow connections with a source of an ecosystem service carrier, but may or may not actually receive the carrier due to the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, potential use identifies areas where it is physically possible for a benefit to be received. For preventive services, potential use identifies areas that may be damaged by a detrimental carrier if sinks do not prevent such damage.
This map shows water actually reaching a user, but not accounting for the activity of sinks.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Actual surface water flow
page.title: Actual surface water flow
page.description:
*Actual flow maps* show the flow paths that deliver actual services to beneficiaries. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
In this case, the density of actual flows shows surface water movement when accounting for flow paths and sinks (i.e., transitions from surface to groundwater, or evapotranspirative losses of surface water).
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Used surface water supply
page.title: Used surface water supply
page.description:
*Actual source maps* show sources that actually provide a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics.
For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier that was neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows sources of surface water that provide water to human beneficiaries when accounting for surface flow paths and sinks.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Actual surface water sink
page.title: Actual surface water sink
page.description:
*Actual sink maps* shows the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns.
For provisioning services, such sinks reduce benefits to users compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows the locations where surface water transitions into groundwater (via infiltration) or atmospheric water (via evapotranspiration), becoming unavailable for use as surface water.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Satisfied surface water demand
page.title: Satisfied surface water demand
page.description:
*Actual use maps* show the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users.
This map shows the portion of water demand satisfied by the actual supply of surface water.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Unusable surface water supply
page.title: Unusable surface water supply
page.description:
*Inaccessible source maps* show source areas whose values are irrelevant to ecosystem service delivery, because of a lack of flow connections between sources and users.
For provisioning services, this is the portion of the value that must be subtracted from the total source map to define a maximum potential benefit for the users. For preventive services, it shows those areas that have no potential of producing damage because the flow dynamics prevent the carrier from impacting any significant user.
This map shows the source locations of surface water that are not available to human users because their flow paths do not move them in a direction where they can be accessed by human beneficiaries.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Inaccessible surface water demand
page.title: Inaccessible surface water demand
page.description:
*Inaccessible use maps* shows potential users that cannot receive a service due to a lack of flow routes linking source and user locations.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment that cannot be reached by users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but is not due to a lack of flow connections to users.
This map shows areas of demand for surface water that goes unsatisfied due to a lack of surface or groundwater flow connections between sources of water and the location of water users.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source:
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Sunk surface water flow
page.title: Sunk surface water flow
page.description:
*Blocked flow maps* show flow paths that could have delivered an ecosystem service to humans based on the flow routes and source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show the loss of possible beneficial service flow to users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the flow paths show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows water flows that fail to reach a user because it encountered a sink and transitioned from surface water into the atmospheric or groundwater.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Sunk surface water supply
page.title: Sunk surface water supply
page.description:
*Blocked source maps* show sources that had the possibility of reaching users given the location of users and flow dynamics, but were blocked from doing so because of the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but lost before it could reach the users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but was blocked by natural features.
This map shows the source locations of surface water that fails to reach a user due to their encountering a sink and transitioning from surface water into the atmosphere or groundwater.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Blocked surface water demand
page.title: Blocked surface water demand
page.description:
*Blocked use maps* show users that would have received a service carrier based on source and flow dynamics, but did not because of the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that were prevented by sinks from reaching users; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users from sinks that blocked damaging flows. For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and sink features.
This map shows demand for surface water that goes unsatisfied due to the action of sinks that transition water from surface water to inaccessible atmospheric moisture or groundwater.
page.see-also: Water supply model details from the ARIES website
page.credits: Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.
